I've found this game to be very enjoyable with a few caveats that I'll get to. It's not an idler but it can be played as an idle-adjacent kind of game, particularly as you get further into the game. That said, I do feel the game plays best as something you pick up for 30-60 minutes at a time and set aside for a bit. 

What I like about is the long term progression and cooperative nature of the game. Everyone invests together, guilds complete events together. Everyone is contributing in ways that help everyone out and I think it's fostered an absolutely terrific community on the official Discord. 

This is exactly the sort of game that I was wanting, something that was multiplayer I could play with friends and had long-term goals but also not feel like I needed to be actively grinding for hours on end. Another thing I really appreciate about this game is that all the events and co-op is asynchronous. What I mean by that is a guild event might run for four days and everyone contributes, but everyone is contributing on their own schedule. Everyone doesn't have to be online at the same time like you might find on a MMO raid or things like that. You play solo, yet everything you are doing helps towards common goals. 

Now for the caveats:

My absolute biggest complaint about this game is mobile-like monetization. I feel like the game is constantly throwing things in my face to spend money on and it's obnoxious. It's particularly obnoxious because while there are absolutely things you can spend money on to create shortcuts or speed things up, the game is completely playable as a F2P player, things will just progress more slowly. As this is a game that already is a marathon and not a sprint I don't find that to be problematic, but the constant attempts to reach into my wallet are a bad look for the game, IMO.

I've been playing the game for a long time even past what my steam account lets on (mobile gaming moment) and I've got very little short of complete praise for the game. I found it through mobile first, figured I'd give it a try and it turned out less predatory* than I expected. Saw it had a steam port, and here I am. To go about it quickly; you run a shop. You hire some heroes to get special materials for you, and meanwhile you use resources from your hired workers (leveled through your cumulative progress with your guildmates) to craft and sell items.

There's a decent bit of depth on most aspects; from what furnitures you put in the shop (which give you energy to immediately craft items + affect what you can sell), to what resource caps you'll have available and how you interact with customers (discount for less gold but more energy? or surcharge for more gold but a big dip in energy). There's constant rotating events to keep you on your toes, though they're the same 4 every month round and important to progress.

Given it's a free game, it has monetisation. That comes in the form of premium workers that offer unique recipes otherwise unavailable *to craft* without having the premium package required to unlock. Although premium gear and items tend to offer higher stats, you can always buy said items from the player market which has a softcap on how high or low you can price items, so no, you're not getting milked for your money in a p2w environment. There's no PvP besides high-end guilds competing for the first spot on a leaderboard in events, and for the most part it's a blend of a single and co-op multiplayer game.

The asterisk for the less predatory practices at the start is for here however. Every few days, packs get released and the game will gently nudge you to one- the pop-ups happen, but they are not intrusive. The game will definitely remind you that premium workers exist any time you try to help your guild with their buildings, and sadly as much as I want to support the game, it's on the pricier end. The workers are one time purchases ranging at the same price as the average AAA game's minor DLCs and that's one pretty penny too much for me, unless I've gone a few months in the game without buying anything.

I really like the game. I think it's charming, it's definitely got a lot (too much almost lol) to sink your teeth into, and it's a chill experience. What it isn't is a power fantasy- you play a slow and chilled marathon with optional grinds, and you get out what you put in. You're free to judge the monetisation for what it is, but I do think it's relatively fair. There's complaints to be made about QoL changes that could be made (i.e. rolling heroes later on could be easier through automation rather than manually clicking the same 7 buttons for upwards of a few hundred attempts... ahem.), and those are valid. But the game is really good for a free to play, and especially for one that's fairly heavily monetised off the cuff.

Give it a shot, but if you do definitely look some stuff up online. Resources are overall few, but they're really helpful for having the most fun as soon as possible. ^^

**Shop Titans** is less an "ultimate RPG shopkeeper simulation" and more a **glorified timer management simulator** draped in fantasy aesthetic. The core loop of crafting, selling at a **markup**, and sending heroes questing quickly devolves into an egregious **free-to-play grind**. Progression, which is already simple and repetitive, hits aggressive paywalls that demand real money to unlock essential crafting specialists and accelerate absurdly long cooldowns. While there's a charming visual layer and a theoretically deep guild system, the entire experience is relentlessly hampered by its mobile-game DNA, forcing you to check in constantly or pay to circumvent the **friction** deliberately engineered into the design. It's a shopkeeping game where the true titan you're serving is the **microtransaction economy**.

I've played this game for a few years now and it's had superior quality in design and rendering compared to almost every mobile game I've played and a few of the similar-styled games out there. For comparison, the dialogue scenes are animated here, whereas most (EG Marvel STRIKE Force) still use static images for character dialogue.

The rotation for the town map and screen rotation for either landscape or portrait modes are also great additions that should be available in more games but have been conspicuously absent, so I've really enjoyed having those here.

Aside from the great design for characters and gear, the character cutomizations are fantastic and the 3D rendering of not just gear but crafting reagents has continued to impress me. You don't normally see the models for crafting reagents, since they only seem to be used when opening treasure chests, but the detail in their design is unparalleled for background items, even in more "serious" gaming. It's all really enriched beyond what I ever expected for a mobile game.

This is a mobile game first, and a PC game last. The game has a ton of problems, that the developers "fix" by offering to sell you a premium worker to mitigate the issue. 
You can sit there multiple hours hiring and retiring until you get a hero who's first two skills(you also need a particular skill in the questing tree to even see the first two skills, otherwise you have to level them up). You have to then level them up to find out their 3rd and possibly 4th skill and fire them if the skill isn't very good. The developers then "fixed" the issue by adding a worker that people can buy which lets you replace one skill per hero with any skill they want. I doubt that fixes the issue, it'll mitigate it.

Another massive issue that I have with the game is how slow selling items is. Customers do not enter your shop while the game is off, nor do they enter your shop when you're in the city view to invest into the city, interact with the market, or anything else in there. The developers again mitigated this issue by making it so that when you ARE able to have the game open long enough for customers to enter your shop by adding a premium worker that you have to buy which speeds up their walking speed for 15 minutes or something. Selling items was so slow that I put my pets away in storage because I didn't want customers to take the extra time to go and pet my pet for a measily 60 energy(when my energy was empty, I got 800-900 energy from each successful small talk, and somewhere in the ballpark of 1000 when I discounted the item).

I also have a massive issue with how much energy higher tiers cost to surcharge. I was in the bartering tree so I had more max energy than normal, Had 74 furniture that I got energy from, 72 of which were level 15+(levelling them up above level 15 costs a currency that you only get more of once a month, and I'd run out of them after a week or two). As a result I had over 9000 energy and there were still some items that I couldn't surcharge because I didn't own the premium worker for them. As a result I couldn't ascend them to reduce their surcharge cost, and I couldn't go into their research tree to reduce their surcharge cost either.

The developers take far too long to patch issues. A guild member of mine eventually quit the game because for months he couldn't see how much an item he relied on selling on the market was worth there before they finally patched it. The developers give very little information within the game so I had to rely on third-party tools to do things like recruit people, as the devs don't tell you within the game when they first started playing, what there record contribution on an event is, or anything.

The devs also banned me from their discord for expressing my sexuality in my profile picture, which plenty of other people in their discord already do and I was in there AND active for a year and a half before they did so.

I've been playing this games for around 5 years now. ( the hours don't reflect because I mostly play on mobile ) 

This is your typical pay to win mobile game. HOWEVER. if you can look past that giant hurdle, the game is actually quite in depth. getting into an active guild makes the experience a bit more enjoyable, and easier. 

This game is a grind to say the least. If you're going to start just know its going to take a few years to get where you want to be. The grind is why I cant recommend this game, even after playing it for this long.

This is a mobile game first, and a PC game last. The game has a ton of problems, that the developers "fix" by offering to sell you a premium worker to mitigate the issue. 
You can sit there multiple hours hiring and retiring until you get a hero who's first two skills(you also need a particular skill in the questing tree to even see the first two skills, otherwise you have to level them up). You have to then level them up to find out their 3rd and possibly 4th skill and fire them if the skill isn't very good. The developers then "fixed" the issue by adding a worker that people can buy which lets you replace one skill per hero with any skill they want. I doubt that fixes the issue, it'll mitigate it.

Another massive issue that I have with the game is how slow selling items is. Customers do not enter your shop while the game is off, nor do they enter your shop when you're in the city view to invest into the city, interact with the market, or anything else in there. The developers again mitigated this issue by making it so that when you ARE able to have the game open long enough for customers to enter your shop by adding a premium worker that you have to buy which speeds up their walking speed for 15 minutes or something. Selling items was so slow that I put my pets away in storage because I didn't want customers to take the extra time to go and pet my pet for a measily 60 energy(when my energy was empty, I got 800-900 energy from each successful small talk, and somewhere in the ballpark of 1000 when I discounted the item).

I also have a massive issue with how much energy higher tiers cost to surcharge. I was in the bartering tree so I had more max energy than normal, Had 74 furniture that I got energy from, 72 of which were level 15+(levelling them up above level 15 costs a currency that you only get more of once a month, and I'd run out of them after a week or two). As a result I had over 9000 energy and there were still some items that I couldn't surcharge because I didn't own the premium worker for them. As a result I couldn't ascend them to reduce their surcharge cost, and I couldn't go into their research tree to reduce their surcharge cost either.

The developers take far too long to patch issues. A guild member of mine eventually quit the game because for months he couldn't see how much an item he relied on selling on the market was worth there before they finally patched it. The developers give very little information within the game so I had to rely on third-party tools to do things like recruit people, as the devs don't tell you within the game when they first started playing, what there record contribution on an event is, or anything.

The devs also banned me from their discord for expressing my sexuality in my profile picture, which plenty of other people in their discord already do and I was in there AND active for a year and a half before they did so.

I've been playing this games for around 5 years now. ( the hours don't reflect because I mostly play on mobile ) 

This is your typical pay to win mobile game. HOWEVER. if you can look past that giant hurdle, the game is actually quite in depth. getting into an active guild makes the experience a bit more enjoyable, and easier. 

This game is a grind to say the least. If you're going to start just know its going to take a few years to get where you want to be. The grind is why I cant recommend this game, even after playing it for this long. 


pro tip; while playing on pc, have it run in the background, or on your 2nd monitor. hop back a fourth between whatever it is your'e doing.

You can only advance your characters in the city by spending the real cash for each one. They do go on sale but if not they are all over $15-$20 for each. This adds up after a short while. In fact, if you add all 33 characters up @ $15/ character it is almost $500USD. I am in Canada so tack on another 30%. Now don't get me wrong some go on sale but some not at all.

There are reasons people play free game is BECAUSE THEY ARE FREE. Please make the game free in all aspects/levels without having to pay to play and continue on. A good example of pay to play would be to have "The Bard" go on sale. I would never pay $25 for a character but he is needed to upgrade two items at one time. In the years I have played this game I have never seen him go on sale. All other characters just give you blueprints that you should be able to get just like the first ones when you start up the game.

I get it the devs have to make a profit but make money with sugar not vinegar. Keep prices lower by a lot and maybe more will buy them. I have seriously debated getting the diamond special in game because I think it would be worth it. But the character upgrades are not worth it for 2 prints and diamonds.

Game looks good, and for what it is, it's decent. The problem is that it is what it is -- a mobile-style game with a freemium and subscription-based progression system. Sure, you can play for hours and hours and eventually scrape together enough resources and have enough luck to unlock most things or maybe even everything, but unless you're intensely into the game mechanics, it'll be a slog.

If you like to play this kind of game *for fun* or you're one of the whales out there who actually have the money to spend on games like these, I'm sure you'll have a great time. For the rest of us? I can't recommend a game like this except when you're on your mobile phone in a waiting room needing to get a few minutes to pass just a little faster and you have nothing better to do.
